physDesc.p: M108 [The Reader: There is a jolt at the points.]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 7p. Paginated 23-28, with an unpaginated page at end.

These and successive folders of [The Reader] were contained in two multigrip folders, headed by Virginia Woolf: "Turning the page"; "Transformations" and "Spare sheets of T.P." labels on the spines. They are filed under her Anon, holograph and typescript fragments.

The fragments grouped in the successive folders under [The reader] may or may not have formed part of Anon. They have been grouped in this fashion based on the evidence of paper and typewriters. The pagination 23-28 is the lowest in the sequence. Internal evidence would indicate that manuscript drafts preceded that of Anon, since Articles, 1938-9 notebook contains a fragment. Some of the versos of this run of material contains fragments of typescripts of Between the Acts and other contemporary works.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

And the play itself was still anonymous. If we could measure the e ec (effect) of the audience upon the play we should have a hold which is denied us upon the play itself. But the audience, drawn though it is by an irrestible (irresistible) attraction to the play, is silent.

That sielnce (silence) is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us and the play. They come crodwing (crowding) across the river daily; but they nxmxmxx sit there silent. They heard their aspirations, their profanities, their ribaldries spoken for them in poetry. And there was always something illicit in their pleasure. The preacher and the magistrate were always denouncing their emotion. That too must have given it intensity.

The proper topics of discccuion (discussion) in the pper (upper) world was not the Play at t e (the) Bankside but the life of man. The titles xxxxxxx of the Essays enumaerate (enumerate) the [illeg.] of those topics. "Of Truth. Of Death. Of Unity in religion. Of Revenge. Of Simulation and Dissumlation (Dissimulation)." These were the subjects that the rulers discussed at their high tables; and the play was a diversion with which to relax the mind after serious work. The sediment of that conversation is to be found in the rich deposits of the essays. He is concern with the great world of action; with government; with the tortuous matures of Princes; with the arts by which Princes can way (sway), can coax, can suppress. He lives entirely in the world of great spirits and great business. The common
peopl (people) is contemptible. The master of superstition is
t e (the) people." Praise, "if it be from the common people,
it is commonly false and naught. The lowest virtues draw praise from them; the middle virtues work in them astonish
ment; and admiration; but of the highest vertues they have no sense or percebing (perceiving) at all."

The soul that walked between delicate groves, now and then formulating a pharse (phrase) to be taken down by the y ng (young) secretary , kept to a narrow path between hedges. While ranged th (the) world, indulgn (indulging) all
curisoities (curiosities), mixing garrul usly (garrulously) with every one, Bacon kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given concrete form.
"Nay retire men acnnot (cannot) when they would: neither will they when it were reason; but are impateint (impatient) of privateness even in age and sickness which require the Shadow: Like old Townmen that will be still sitting at their street door,
though thereby they offer Age to scorn." Even in the thought ic (is) coloured. The Colours that show best by candlelight , are: White, Carnation, and a kinde of Sea-Water Green". It only needs the playwright to put one push for their thoughts flesh and blood onto his thoughts. to become [people?]

Bacons contempt was for hyperbole; not for the art of speech. He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely, subtly. He was proving that there is anothe (another) kind of poetry, the poetry of prose. He was bringing the prose of the mind into being. And thus by increasing the range of the poet, bu making it possible for him to express more, he was making an end of anonymity.
